title: Solomon's Downfall
shortSummary: This chapter details King Solomon's failure to remain faithful to God due to his many foreign wives who led him into idolatry. As a result, God pronounces judgment, promising to divide the kingdom after Solomon's reign, setting the stage for the eventual split of Israel. The chapter highlights the consequences of disobedience and the faithfulness of God's covenant promises to David.
timeline: c. 970-931 BC - Reign of Solomon, late period

keyCharacters.name: Solomon
keyCharacters.description: The wise king of Israel who, despite his wisdom and initial faithfulness, falls into idolatry influenced by his foreign wives, leading to God's judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Hadad the Edomite
keyCharacters.description: An adversary raised up by God against Solomon, a member of the royal line of Edom who fled to Egypt and later sought to return to challenge Solomon's rule.

keyCharacters.name: Rezon
keyCharacters.description: Another adversary stirred up by God, who became king over Damascus and opposed Israel during Solomon's reign.

keyCharacters.name: Jeroboam
keyCharacters.description: An official under Solomon who rebelled against him; God promised to give him ten tribes of Israel to rule after Solomon's reign.

keyCharacters.name: Ahijah the Shilonite
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who delivered God's message to Jeroboam, symbolically tearing his garment to signify the division of the kingdom.

definitions.definition: A woman who lives with a man but has lower status than his wife or wives; often used in ancient times for political alliances or to increase offspring.
A site, often elevated, used for worship, sometimes associated with idolatrous practices forbidden by God.
An opponent or enemy; in this chapter, those raised by God to oppose Solomon as a form of judgment.
To tear apart or divide; used here metaphorically for God’s promise to divide Solomon’s kingdom.
God’s laws or decrees given to Israel to guide their conduct and worship.

outline.heading: Solomon’s Idolatry Through Foreign Wives
outline.description: Solomon’s love for many foreign women leads him to idolatry, building high places for their gods and turning his heart away from the LORD, violating God’s commands.

outline.heading: God’s Judgment Pronounced
outline.description: Because Solomon’s heart turned from God, the LORD declares He will tear the kingdom from Solomon’s son but will preserve one tribe for David’s sake.

outline.heading: Enemies Raised Against Solomon
outline.description: God stirs up adversaries Hadad the Edomite and Rezon of Damascus to oppose Solomon, signaling the beginning of political instability.

outline.heading: Jeroboam’s Rise and Prophetic Promise
outline.description: Jeroboam rebels against Solomon; the prophet Ahijah reveals God’s plan to give Jeroboam ten tribes, while Solomon seeks to kill him, forcing Jeroboam to flee to Egypt.

outline.heading: Conclusion of Solomon’s Reign
outline.description: The chapter closes with a summary of Solomon’s reign, his death, and the succession of his son Rehoboam.

application: Guard your heart against influences that can lead you away from God’s commands, especially in relationships.
Recognize that God’s blessings come with responsibilities to obey His statutes fully and that disobedience brings consequences.
Trust in God’s faithfulness to His covenant promises even when judgment is pronounced, as seen in His mercy toward David’s line.
Be attentive to God’s warnings through His word and prophets, responding with repentance and obedience.

keyVerses.text: For it came to pass, when Solomon was old, that his wives turned away his heart after other gods: and his heart was not perfect with the LORD his God, as was the heart of David his father.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the spiritual decline of Solomon, contrasting his heart with that of David and explaining the root cause of his downfall.

keyVerses.text: Wherefore the LORD said unto Solomon, Forasmuch as this is done of thee, and thou hast not kept my covenant and my statutes, which I have commanded thee, I will surely rend the kingdom from thee, and will give it to thy servant.
keyVerses.significance: God’s judgment is clearly pronounced here, emphasizing the seriousness of covenant disobedience and the consequences for Solomon’s dynasty.

keyVerses.text: And he said to Jeroboam, Take thee ten pieces: for thus saith the LORD, the God of Israel, Behold, I will rend the kingdom out of the hand of Solomon, and will give ten tribes to thee:
keyVerses.significance: This prophetic promise reveals God’s plan to divide the kingdom and establishes Jeroboam as the future ruler of the ten northern tribes.

keyVerses.text: And Solomon slept with his fathers, and was buried in the city of David his father: and Rehoboam his son reigned in his stead.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the end of Solomon’s reign and the beginning of a new era under Rehoboam, setting the stage for the kingdom’s division.
